text.__SUMMARY__: Ulmus glaucescens var. lasiocarpa Rehder, named the hairy-fruited glaucescent elm in the United States, is a Chinese tree found along rivers and mountain slopes at elevations of 2500–2600 m in the provinces of Hebei, Henan, Liaoning, Nei Mongol, Ningxia, eastern Qinghai, and Shanxi.
text.Description: The variety is distinguished by a "samara densely pubescent when young, with scattered hairs when mature. Fl. and fr. March–May.".
text.Pests and diseases: The tree was heavily damaged by the elm leaf beetle Xanthogaleruca luteola in trials in Oklahoma.
text.Cultivation: There are no known cultivars of this taxon, nor is it known to be in commerce.
text.Accessions-North America:
Morton Arboretum, US. Acc. no. 537-76: two trees raised from seed sent by the Beijing Botanical Garden, one in the China garden, central section, another along the Du Page River.
United States National Arboretum, Washington, D.C., US. Acc. no. 76255.
text.Accessions-Europe: Grange Farm Arboretum, Lincolnshire, UK. Two grafted trees from cuttings ex Morton. Acc. no. 700.
text.Accessions-Australasia:
Mount Lofty Botanic Garden, Piccadilly, Australia. One tree, raised from seed sent by the Beijing Botanical Garden, planted out c. 1984, 4.5 m high, d.b.h. 13 cm in 2008.
